As the businessman looked around in the aircraft, it became obvious that many passengers were becoming a bit  [MASK]  .
Lightning  lit up  the darkening skies, and within moments that great plane was like a  [MASK]  moving around on an ocean.
One moment the airplane was  [MASK]  on terrific currents of air; the next, it dropped as if it were about to crash.
The future seemed terrible and many were wondering if they would  [MASK]  it through the storm.
Obviously the storm meant  [MASK]  to her.
She was reading a book and everything within her small world was  [MASK]  and orderly.
Sometimes she closed her eyes, then she would  [MASK]  again; then she would straighten her legs, but worry and fear were not in her  world  .
Sometimes she closed her eyes, then she would  read  again; then she would straighten her legs, but worry and fear were not in her  [MASK]  .
All the adults were scared half to  [MASK]  , but the great child wasn't afraid at all.
When the plane finally  [MASK]  its destination, he asked why she had not been afraid.
There are many kinds of storms that  [MASK]  us physically, mentally and financially.
And many storms can easily and quickly darken our skies and  [MASK]  out planes into uncontrollable movement.

Research has shown that two-thirds of human conversation is taken up not with discussion of the cultural or political problems of the day, not heated debates about films we've just watched or books we've just finished reading, but plain and simple  [MASK]  .
Language is our greatest treasure as a species, and what do we  [MASK]  do with it?

About others' behaviour and private lives, such as who's doing what with whom, who's in and who's out-and why; how to deal with difficult  [MASK]  situations involving children, lovers, and colleagues.
Are we just natural  [MASK]  , of both time and words?
In fact, in his latest book, Grooming, Gossip and the Evolution of Language, the psychologist says gossip is one of these really  [MASK]  issues.

Dunbar  [MASK]  the traditional view that language was developed by the men at the early stage of social development in order to organize their manly hunting activities more effectively, or even to promote the exchange of poetic stories about their origins and the supernatural.
Dunbar arrived at his cheery theory by studying the  [MASK]  of the higher primates like monkeys.

By means of grooming--cleaning the fur by brushing it, monkeys form groups with other individuals on whom they can rely for support in the event of some kind of conflict within the group or  [MASK]  from outside it.
As we human beings evolve from a particular branch of the primate family, Dunbar  [MASK]  that at one time in our history we did much the same.
Grouping together made sense because the bigger the group, the greater the  [MASK]  it provided; on the other hand, the bigger the group, the greater the stresses of living close to others.
Grooming helped to  [MASK]  the pressure and calm everybody down.
But as the groups got bigger and bigger, the amount of time spent in grooming activities also had to be  [MASK]  to maintain its effectiveness.

Clearly, a more  [MASK]  kind of grooming was needed, and thus language evolved as a kind of vocal grooming which allowed humans to develop relationship with ever-larger groups by exchanging information over a wider network of individuals than would be possible by one-to-one  physical  contact.

The ride began on a beautiful Sunday morning in the Georgia countryside,and for the first few hours I felt  wonderful  .This was just the experience I had  [MASK]  ,and my spirits were high.
[MASK]  by the end of the day,I felt tired out.
If the body is  [MASK]  to the mind,here was evidence.
Every  [MASK]  my brain pushed out seemed to travel right down to my legs.
"I can't handle this" became a leg cramp ,and "Everyone else is a better rider" translated into  [MASK]  of breath.
I was sure I'd have to  [MASK]  .
Then in the distance,I saw a lone woman riding very slowly  [MASK]  the bright red sun.
I  [MASK]  that the person looked different in some way,but I couldn't tell why.
So I pushed myself to  catch up  .There she was,riding along slowly but  [MASK]  ,with a slight and determined smile on her face and she had only one leg.
For a whole day I'd been  [MASK]  my body.
But now I knew it wasn't the body,but the  [MASK]  that would help me reach my goal.
I never saw the one-legged biker again,but I pushed on without  [MASK]  ,knowing she was out there with me somewhere.
And at the end of the day,still feeling  [MASK]  ,I completed the 150mile trip.

"I've   [MASK]   these," he said, handing me a bag.
"She would have wanted you to   [MASK]  them."
I opened the bag to find dozens of   [MASK]   , each one wrapped  in white tissue paper and bearing Mom's handwritten words: Stone Harbor, N.J.--8-98.
They were pretty   [MASK]   , but to Mom, they were evidence of her endlessly magical life.
She was 61 when she collected these shells, already showing   [MASK]   of the lung disease that would kill her the next year.
We just knew something was   [MASK]   and Mom needed an adventure.
She   [MASK]   dinner and a movie.
However, two friends and I had   [MASK]   ideas.
We wanted to take her to Jersey Shore,   [MASK]   my working-class mother had been to the ocean only twice.
She loved the   [MASK]  .
When I called Mom with our   [MASK]   , she was sitting on the couch with her dog Amber on her leg.
When I told her she'd be able to hear the   [MASK]   from her window, she started to cry.
As soon as we got to Stone Harbor, Mom acted like the town mayor  ,    [MASK]   everyone as if they were loyal constituents   .
The morning we   [MASK]  , I found her photographing every inch of her bedroom.
"I don't even want to   [MASK]   this," she said.
Last month, I   [MASK]   them.
One by one, the shells are finding a   [MASK]   place in my home.
I put them where I'm   [MASK]   to see them.
They   [MASK]   me to live a life like my mother--who never lost her sense of wonder.

As I looked outside the car window to my right, there was a small park where I  [MASK]  a little boy, around one and a half to two years old,  running  freely on the grass as his mother watched from a short distance.

As I looked outside the car window to my right, there was a small park where I  saw  a little boy, around one and a half to two years old,  [MASK]  freely on the grass as his mother watched from a short distance.
The boy would then fall to the grass, get up, and without  [MASK]  or without looking back at his mother, run as fast as he could, again, still with a smile on his face.
It seemed  [MASK]  had happened!
For kids,  [MASK]  at an early age, when they fall down, they don't regard their falling down as a  failure  ;instead, they treat it as a learning experience.
For kids,  especially  at an early age, when they fall down, they don't regard their falling down as a  [MASK]  ;instead, they treat it as a learning experience.
The answer must be that they have not  [MASK]  "falling down" with the word "failure" yet, thus they don' t know how to feel the state which accomparues failure.
Therefore, they are not  [MASK]  in any way.
Touched as I was by the boy's  [MASK]  , I was equally touched by the manner in which he ran.
With each attempt, he looked so  [MASK]  and natural.
No  [MASK]  of fear and nervousness.
His only aim was to run freely and to do it as  [MASK]  as he could.
He was not looking for  [MASK]  or was not worrying about whether someone was  watching  or not.
He was not looking for  approval  or was not worrying about whether someone was  [MASK]  or not.
He didn't seem to be bothered by the fact that maybe someone would see him fall ( as there were others in the park apart from him and his mother) and that it would be  [MASK]  if he did fall.
No, all that  [MASK]  to him was to accomplish the task or activity at hand to the best of his ability.
I  [MASK]  a lot from that observation and experience, and have successfully brought that lesson with me in my many pursuits in life.

Dried shark fins are used to make shark fin soup, which sells for as much as $50 a bowl in fine Hong Kong  [MASK]  .
Sharks are vulnerable  to overfishing because it  [MASK]  most species 10 to 15 years to begin reproducing and they produce only a few offspring.
[MASK]  by movies and popular novels, most people see sharks as people-eating monsters.
This is far from the  [MASK]  .
Most  [MASK]  are by great white sharks, which often feed on sea lions and other marine mammals.
They sometimes mistake human swimmers for their normal prey,  [MASK]  if they are wearing black wet suits.
If you are a typical ocean-goer, your  [MASK]  of being killed by an unprovoked  attack by a shark are about 1 in 100 million.
You are more  [MASK]  to be killed by a pig than a shark and thousands of times more likely to get killed when you drive a car.
Sharks help  [MASK]  human lives.
In addition to providing people with food, they are helping us learn how to  [MASK]  cancer, bacteria, and viruses.
Their highly effective immune system  [MASK]  wounds to heal quickly without becoming infected, and their blood is being studied in connection with AIDS research.
Sharks are among the few animals in the world that almost  [MASK]  get cancer and eye cataracts.
Understanding why can help us improve human  [MASK]  .

My name is Richie Jewell.I'm 20 years old and I've been diagnosed with autism since the age of 2.I'd like to   [MASK]   my story with you about my life with autism.

Firstly,autism makes me a loner.I can't easily   [MASK]   too much human-to-human communication at the same time.I find it difficult to process all that spoken and unspoken information.I also   go through   some other stuff that has been a rocky roadblock during my life.It's very   challenging   to live through the times that I endured during my life   such as   teasing,struggling to adapt to new   places   like schools,on and off depression,  helplessly   seeing my relative's death and the struggles with my disability.Well despite all of those horrible   barriers   that tried to cut me down,I have overcome them.

Many students talked about the rules that they have in school.At their school, they have to wear uniforms every day.The problem is that all the students think the uniforms are  [MASK]  .They think young people should look smart and so they would like to  wear  their own clothes.Their teachers believe that if they did that, they would think more of their clothes than their  study  .But the students disagree.They would  feel  more comfortable and that is good for studying.If they can't do that, they should be allowed to design their own uniforms.That would be a good way to keep both teachers and students happy.It's also probably a good idea for parents to allow teenagers to study in groups during the evening.Sometimes they get noisy  but  they can learn a lot from each other.They also think that vacations should be  longer  .At present they're too short.Longer vacations would give them time to do things like volunteering.Last summer they had an  opportunity  to volunteer at the local  hospital  , but they couldn't because they had to  go back  to school.It would be a good experience  for  them because some of them want to be doctors when they grow up.
